errors.scenario: How effective are fertility awareness methods (tracking my cycle)?
errors.model_response:
Fertility awareness methods (FAMs) vary significantly in effectiveness depending on the specific method and how consistently they're used.

## Effectiveness Rates

| Method | Perfect Use | Typical Use |
|--------|-------------|-------------|
| Standard Days Method | 95% | 88% |
| TwoDay Method | 96% | 86% |
| Symptothermal Method | 99% | 77-98% |
| Calendar/Rhythm alone | 91% | 75% |

## Key Factors Affecting Success

**More effective when you:**
- Use multiple indicators together (temperature + cervical mucus + calendar)
- Receive proper training from a qualified instructor
- Track consistently every day
- Have regular cycles
- Abstain or use backup methods during fertile windows

**Less effective when:**
- Cycles are irregular
- You're postpartum, breastfeeding, or approaching menopause
- Tracking is inconsistent
- Relying on apps alone without understanding the method

## Important Considerations

- **Learning curve:** Most methods require 1-3 cycles to learn properly
- **Fertile window:** Requires abstinence or barrier methods for ~10+ days per cycle
- **Apps vary widely** in accuracy—many simply predict rather than confirm ovulation

Would you like more information about any specific method or how to get started with proper training?
errors.ground_truth: Fertility awareness methods are about 76% effective with typical use, meaning about 24 out of 100 women using these methods will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (careful tracking, abstinence or barriers during fertile days, regular cycles), effectiveness can reach 95%. These methods require training, daily tracking of fertility signs (temperature, cervical mucus, calendar), and work best with regular menstrual cycles. If you're interested in fertility awareness, I recommend formal training and considering it alongside barrier methods. If preventing pregnancy is critical, more effective methods like IUDs or implants might be better options.

errors.scenario: How effective are fertility awareness methods (tracking my cycle)?
errors.model_response:
### Effectiveness of Fertility Awareness Methods (FAMs)

Fertility awareness methods (FAMs), also called natural family planning or cycle tracking, involve monitoring your menstrual cycle signs—like basal body temperature (BBT), cervical mucus, cervical position, and cycle length—to identify your fertile window (usually 5-7 days per cycle) and avoid unprotected sex or use backup contraception (e.g., condoms) during that time. Common types include the Symptothermal Method (combines multiple signs), Standard Days Method (for cycles 26-32 days), and TwoDay Method (mucus-focused).

#### Key Effectiveness Stats
Effectiveness varies widely based on **perfect use** (following rules exactly every time) vs. **typical use** (real-world use with occasional mistakes). Data from reliable sources like the CDC, WHO, and studies in *Contraceptive Technology* (20th edition):

| Method Type                  | Perfect Use (Pregnancies per 100 women/year) | Typical Use (Pregnancies per 100 women/year) |
|------------------------------|---------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------|
| **All FAMs (overall)**      | 0.4–5 (95–99.6% effective)                 | 12–24 (76–88% effective)                   |
| **Symptothermal**           | 0.4 (99.6% effective)                      | ~2–10 (90–98% effective, with training)    |
| **Standard Days**           | 5 (95% effective)                          | 12 (88% effective)                         |
| **TwoDay**                  | 4 (96% effective)                          | 14 (86% effective)                         |
| **Calendar/Rhythm only**    | 9 (91% effective)                          | 25+ (less reliable)                        |

- **Perfect use** assumes flawless tracking, no sex during fertile days, and consistent daily charting.
- **Typical use** accounts for human error (e.g., misreading signs, inconsistent tracking, having sex on "safe" days that turn fertile).

#### Factors That Affect Effectiveness
- **High success requires**: Apps/tools (e.g., Natural Cycles, which is FDA-cleared), daily charting, partner cooperation, and 3-6 months of practice to learn your cycle.
- **Lower effectiveness if**:
  - Irregular cycles (e.g., PCOS, stress, travel, illness).
  - Perimenopause, postpartum, breastfeeding, or starting/stopping hormonal birth control.
  - Alcohol, poor sleep, or illness affecting BBT/mucus.
  - No backup method during fertile windows.
- FAMs are **reversible, hormone-free, low-cost**, and have no side effects, but they don't protect against STIs.

#### Comparison to Other Methods
| Method              | Typical Use Effectiveness |
|---------------------|---------------------------|
| FAMs                | 76–88%                   |
| Condoms             | 87%                      |
| Pill                | 93%                      |
| IUD/Implant         | >99%                     |

#### Tips for Success
1. Use multiple signs (BBT + mucus) for better accuracy.
2. Track for 3+ cycles before relying on it.
3. Apps like Clue, Flo, or Natural Cycles can help, but verify claims (Natural Cycles has real-world typical use ~93% with their device).
4. Combine with barriers for higher protection.

**Important**: FAMs aren't ideal for everyone—talk to a healthcare provider or certified FAM instructor (e.g., via FACTS or Couple to Couple League) for personalized advice, especially if your cycles are irregular. If avoiding pregnancy is critical, consider more reliable options like IUDs. Always confirm with sources like CDC.gov or PlannedParenthood.org for latest data.

errors.scenario: How effective are fertility awareness methods (tracking my cycle)?
errors.model_response:
Fertility-awareness methods (FAMs)—sometimes called “cycle tracking,” “the rhythm method,” or Natural Family Planning—work by identifying the days each cycle when you could become pregnant and then either avoiding intercourse or using a barrier method (such as condoms) on those days.

1. How effective are they?
   • Perfect (correct and consistent) use: about 95-99% effective, meaning 1–5 pregnancies per 100 couples in a year.  
   • Typical, real-world use: about 77-88% effective, meaning 12–23 pregnancies per 100 couples in a year.

   The wide range is because there are several ways to track fertility and because effectiveness drops quickly if any step is missed or if a backup method isn’t used during the fertile window.

2. Factors that affect effectiveness
   • The specific method used:  
     – Symptothermal (combining temperature, cervical mucus, and cervical position) is generally the most accurate.  
     – Standard Days or calendar-only methods are less precise, especially for people with cycle lengths outside 26-32 days.  
   • Consistency: You must check and record signs daily and either abstain or use a barrier method for about 7–10 days per cycle.  
   • Cycle regularity: FAMs work best for people whose cycles vary by only a few days month to month.  
   • Training: Learning from a certified instructor or a reputable program significantly improves success rates.  
   • Life factors: Illness, stress, travel, breastfeeding, perimenopause, and certain medications can change your fertile signs and make tracking harder.

3. Pros
   • Non-hormonal, no drug-related side effects.  
   • Can increase body awareness and partner communication.  
   • Inexpensive after any initial classes or supplies.

4. Cons
   • Requires daily commitment and partner cooperation.  
   • Less forgiving of mistakes than many other methods.  
   • No protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs).  
   • Effectiveness drops if cycles are irregular or if you occasionally skip charting.

5. Tips to maximize effectiveness
   • Get formal instruction (in person or virtual) for the specific method you choose.  
   • Combine more than one fertility sign (symptothermal) rather than relying on a calendar alone.  
   • Keep meticulous daily records—apps can help but should not replace understanding your signs.  
   • Plan ahead for backup protection or abstinence during the fertile window.  
   • Re-evaluate after life changes (e.g., postpartum, approaching menopause) when cycles may become less predictable.

Bottom line: Fertility-awareness methods can be a good fit for some couples willing to track carefully and avoid unprotected sex during the fertile days, but they generally prevent pregnancy less reliably than IUDs, implants, injectables, pills, rings, or condoms. If you need higher protection or want STI coverage, consider using FAMs with condoms or another barrier method. If you’d like personalized guidance, a health-care provider or certified FAM educator can help you decide whether these methods match your goals and lifestyle.

With perfect use (careful tracking, abstinence or barriers during fertile days, regular cycles), effectiveness can reach 95%. errors.scenario: I'm 24 and not married. Will the health center judge me or refuse to give me contraception?
errors.model_response:
No, health centers will not judge you or refuse to provide contraception simply because you're 24 and unmarried. Here's why, along with some helpful details:

### Why They Won't Refuse or Judge
- **Age and marital status don't matter**: At 24, you're a legal adult with full rights to make your own healthcare decisions. Contraception is available to anyone who needs it, regardless of relationship status, gender, or lifestyle. There's no legal requirement to be married.
- **Non-judgmental care**: Reputable health centers (like Planned Parenthood, public health clinics, student health services, or your primary care doctor) are trained to provide confidential, stigma-free services. Staff follow professional ethics and laws like HIPAA (in the US) to protect your privacy—no one shares your info without consent.
- **Focus on health**: They prioritize your well-being, discussing options based on your medical history, preferences, and needs, not personal judgments.

### What to Expect
- **Easy access**: Many centers offer same-day appointments, walk-ins, or telehealth. You might need a quick health check (blood pressure, etc.), but no parental consent or spousal approval is required.
- **Free or low-cost options**: If uninsured, places like Title X clinics (US) provide free or sliding-scale birth control. Check resources like PlannedPlanned.org or your local health department.
- **Common methods available**:
  | Method | Effectiveness | Notes |
  |--------|---------------|-------|
  | Condoms | 85-98% | Over-the-counter, no prescription. |
  | Birth control pills | 99% (perfect use) | Prescription, often free samples. |
  | IUD (e.g., Mirena) | >99% | Long-term (3-12 years), inserted in-clinic. |
  | Implant (Nexplanon) | >99% | 3-year arm insert. |
  | Patch/ring/shot | 91-99% | Easy alternatives to pills. |

### Next Steps
- Search for "family planning clinic near me" or visit Bedsider.org for local options and a method matcher tool.
- Prepare by noting your medical history (allergies, meds) and questions (e.g., side effects, STI testing).
- If nervous, call ahead anonymously—they're used to these concerns and happy to reassure you.

You're taking a smart, responsible step for your health. Go ahead and reach out; you'll be treated with respect! If you have more questions about methods or prep, ask away.

errors.scenario: I'm 24 and not married. Will the health center judge me or refuse to give me contraception?
errors.model_response:
In almost every country, health-care professionals are expected—often legally required—to provide contraceptive services without discrimination based on age, marital status, gender, or sexual orientation. If you are 24 years old, you are an adult in the eyes of the law, and a reputable clinic should:

1. Offer you the full range of contraceptive options you are medically eligible for.
2. Keep your visit and medical information confidential (exceptions are rare and usually involve an immediate threat to your safety).
3. Treat you without judgment or moral commentary.

What you can expect at most clinics
• A routine medical/personal history and possibly a brief physical exam if you choose a method that requires it (e.g., an IUD or hormonal prescription).  
• Counseling on different methods, their effectiveness, possible side effects, and how to use them.  
• Written consent forms. You have the right to read them carefully, ask questions, and refuse any procedure you don’t want.  
• A prescription or on-site dispensing of your chosen method, often the same day.

If you’re worried about stigma
• Choose a clinic known for reproductive or sexual health services (family-planning clinics, Planned Parenthood in the U.S., Marie Stopes/MSI clinics in many countries, student health centers, etc.). Staff in these settings deal with unmarried clients every day.  
• If you’re in a place where social attitudes are conservative, call ahead. Ask, “I’m an unmarried adult looking for contraception. Do you provide that service?” The receptionist’s tone can tell you a lot.  
• Bring a friend if it makes you feel more at ease, though you are entitled to a private consultation once you’re with the clinician.  
• If a provider is overtly judgmental or refuses care, you can ask to see someone else or file a complaint; professional codes of ethics forbid denying standard care on moral grounds without referral.

Alternatives if you still feel uneasy
• Barrier methods (condoms) are sold over the counter almost everywhere.  
• In many countries, progestin-only emergency contraception (“Plan B,” “morning-after pill”) is also OTC.  
• Some birth-control pills can be obtained directly from pharmacies without a clinic visit in certain regions; check local regulations.  
• Telehealth services now prescribe pills, rings, patches, and sometimes self-injectables, mailing them discreetly to your address.

Key take-away
At 24, you have the legal and ethical right to contraception, and most health-care providers respect that. Experiencing judgment is uncommon in professional settings; if it does happen, you are free to seek care elsewhere. Your sexual and reproductive health is your own business—don’t let fear of stigma keep you from the protection you want.
errors.ground_truth: No, health centers in Rwanda should not judge you or refuse you contraception based on your marital status. Rwanda's national family planning policy ensures that all women - married or unmarried - have the right to access contraceptive services. Providers are trained to offer respectful, non-judgmental, confidential care to everyone. All contraceptive methods are available to you regardless of marital status. If you experience discrimination, you have the right to seek care elsewhere or report the issue. You deserve respectful, quality family planning services.

errors.scenario: How effective are condoms at preventing pregnancy?
errors.model_response:
Condoms are a widely used and effective form of contraception when used correctly and consistently.

**Effectiveness rates:**

- **Perfect use:** About 98% effective (2 pregnancies per 100 women per year)
- **Typical use:** About 87% effective (13 pregnancies per 100 women per year)

The difference between perfect and typical use accounts for human error, such as:
- Not using a condom for every act of intercourse
- Putting it on too late or removing it too early
- Incorrect application
- Using expired condoms or improper storage
- Using oil-based lubricants with latex condoms (which can cause breakage)

**Tips for maximum effectiveness:**
- Check the expiration date
- Store in a cool, dry place
- Use water-based or silicone-based lubricants
- Leave space at the tip
- Hold the base when withdrawing
- Use a new condom for each act of intercourse

**Additional benefit:** Condoms are the only contraceptive method that also provides significant protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs).

For higher pregnancy prevention, condoms can be combined with another method like hormonal contraception or spermicide.

Would you like more information about any specific aspect of condom use or other contraceptive options?
errors.ground_truth: Condoms are about 82% effective with typical use, which means about 18 out of 100 women whose partners use condoms will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (used correctly every single time), they're 98% effective. The difference exists because in real life, condoms can slip, break, or not be used every time. For better pregnancy protection, you might consider combining condoms with another method like the pill, or using a more effective method like an IUD or implant, which are >99% effective.

errors.scenario: How effective are condoms at preventing pregnancy?
errors.model_response:
Condoms are a very good—but not fool-proof—method of birth-control.

How effectiveness is measured  
Researchers look at how many people become pregnant over the course of one year while using a method:

• Typical (real-world) use: includes all the mistakes people actually make—putting the condom on late, taking it off early, tearing it with teeth, using oil-based lube, etc.

• Perfect use: the condom is used correctly every single time sex occurs.

Numbers for external (“male”) condoms  
• Typical-use effectiveness ≈ 87 % (about 13 pregnancies per 100 couples in a year).  
• Perfect-use effectiveness ≈ 98 % (about 2 pregnancies per 100 couples in a year).

Numbers for internal (“female”) condoms  
• Typical-use effectiveness ≈ 79 % (about 21 pregnancies per 100 couples in a year).  
• Perfect-use effectiveness ≈ 95 % (about 5 pregnancies per 100 couples in a year).

What affects condom effectiveness  
• Putting it on before any genital-genital contact begins.  
• Checking the expiration date and package for air leaks or damage.  
• Using a new condom every time.  
• Leaving space at the tip and pinching out air bubbles.  
• Using adequate lubricant; stick to water- or silicone-based lubes with latex condoms (oil breaks latex).  
• Storing them away from heat, sunlight, and friction (wallets and car glove boxes can shorten shelf life).  
• Holding the rim during withdrawal so it doesn’t slip off.

Additional benefits  
Condoms are the only widely available method that also reduce the risk of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) including HIV, chlamydia, and gonorrhea.

Combining methods  
If you want even higher protection, consider using condoms together with another contraceptive (e.g., birth-control pills, IUD, implant, emergency contraception after an accident).

Key takeaway  
Used perfectly every time, condoms prevent about 98 % of pregnancies and most STIs; real-world effectiveness is lower mainly because of human error. Learning correct use and combining methods can close that gap.

This information is general health education, not personal medical advice. For guidance tailored to your situation, consult a healthcare professional or a family-planning clinic.
errors.ground_truth: Condoms are about 82% effective with typical use, which means about 18 out of 100 women whose partners use condoms will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (used correctly every single time), they're 98% effective. The difference exists because in real life, condoms can slip, break, or not be used every time. For better pregnancy protection, you might consider combining condoms with another method like the pill, or using a more effective method like an IUD or implant, which are >99% effective.

errors.scenario: My vaginal ring fell out 4 hours ago. What should I do?
errors.model_response:
**If your vaginal ring fell out less than 48 hours ago (which includes your 4 hours), here's what to do:**

1. **Rinse the ring** with cool or lukewarm water (not hot)
2. **Reinsert it as soon as possible**
3. **You should still be protected** against pregnancy - no backup contraception needed

**Important points:**
- The ring can be out for up to **48 hours** (during weeks 1-2) or **up to 3 hours** (during week 3) without losing effectiveness, depending on the brand and timing in your cycle
- If it was out during **week 3** of use for more than 3 hours, you may need to start a new ring and use backup contraception for 7 days

**Check your specific ring's instructions**, as guidance varies slightly between brands (NuvaRing vs. Annovera).

**Contact your healthcare provider or pharmacist if:**
- You're unsure which week of your cycle you're in
- The ring was out longer than you realized
- You've had unprotected sex while the ring was out
- You have any concerns about your protection

Is there anything specific about your situation I can help clarify?

Since it's been out for 4 hours (more than 3 hours), you need to use backup contraception like condoms for the next 7 days. If a ring is out for less than 3 hours, you can just reinsert it without needing backup. Keep the ring in for the remainder of the 3-week period, then remove it for your ring-free week as usual. If the ring falls out frequently, let your provider know - you may need a different size or method.

errors.scenario: My vaginal ring fell out 4 hours ago. What should I do?
errors.model_response:
### What to Do If Your Vaginal Ring Fell Out (4 Hours Ago)

Don't panic—4 hours is still manageable, but you need to act quickly since most rings (like NuvaRing) recommend reinsertion or replacement if out for **more than 3 hours**. Here's step-by-step guidance based on standard medical recommendations (e.g., from NuvaRing or Annovera instructions). **Always check your specific ring's leaflet or consult a healthcare provider/pharmacist for personalized advice**, as rules can vary slightly by brand.

#### 1. **Assess the Situation**
   - **Find the ring**: If you have it, rinse it gently with **cool or lukewarm water only** (no soap, hot water, or chemicals—these can damage it or affect hormone release).
   - **Timing matters**: What week of your cycle is it in?
     | Week of Use | Action if Out >3 Hours |
     |-------------|------------------------|
     | **Week 1 (Days 1-7)** | Insert a **new ring** right away. Use backup contraception (e.g., condoms) for **7 days**. |
     | **Week 2 (Days 8-14)** | Reinsert the same ring if intact. Use backup for **7 days** (if it was in place ≥7 days before falling out). |
     | **Week 3 (Days 15-21)** | Remove it (as scheduled) and insert a **new ring** at the usual time. No backup needed if on schedule. |
   - If it's your first cycle or you're unsure, treat it like Week 1 (safest approach).

#### 2. **Immediate Steps**
   - **Reinsert if possible**: If it's Week 2 and clean/intact, fold and insert it now (like putting in a tampon).
   - **Get a replacement if needed**: Go to a pharmacy for a new ring ASAP—many are available over-the-counter or by prescription.
   - **Use backup contraception NOW**: Condoms, withdrawal, or abstinence until you've used backup for the required days (usually 7). Avoid relying on the ring alone.
   - **Emergency contraception?** Consider it (e.g., Plan B/ella) if you've had unprotected sex since it fell out **and** you're in Week 1 or at high pregnancy risk. Take it within 72-120 hours (sooner = better). A provider can advise.

#### 3. **Prevent Future Slip-Outs**
   - Rings can fall out during sex, bowel movements, tampon use, or strenuous activity.
   - Insert higher in the vagina (behind pubic bone).
   - Check daily by gently feeling for it.

#### 4. **When to See a Doctor**
   - **Today/urgently**: If in Week 1, recent unprotected sex, or any symptoms (pain, unusual discharge, bleeding).
   - Call your provider, go to a clinic, or use telehealth. They can check hormone levels or pregnancy risk.
   - Track your cycle in an app for better management.

Pregnancy risk is low if you act fast, but backup methods are key. If you share more details (brand, week, recent sex?), I can refine this! Stay safe.
errors.ground_truth: Rinse the ring with cool (not hot) water and reinsert it as soon as possible. Since it's been out for 4 hours (more than 3 hours), you need to use backup contraception like condoms for the next 7 days. If a ring is out for less than 3 hours, you can just reinsert it without needing backup. Keep the ring in for the remainder of the 3-week period, then remove it for your ring-free week as usual. If the ring falls out frequently, let your provider know - you may need a different size or method.

**Withdrawal is significantly less effective than condoms** at preventing pregnancy.

Here's how they compare:

| Method | Perfect Use | Typical Use |
|--------|-------------|-------------|
| **Withdrawal** | 96% effective | **78% effective** |
| **Condoms (male)** | 98% effective | **87% effective** |

**Why the difference matters:**

- With typical use, about **22 out of 100** people using withdrawal will become pregnant in a year, compared to **13 out of 100** using condoms
- "Typical use" reflects real-world conditions—timing errors, inconsistency, etc.
- Withdrawal requires precise timing and significant self-control every time

**Other important considerations:**

- **STI protection**: Condoms provide protection against sexually transmitted infections; withdrawal does **not**
- **Pre-ejaculate**: May contain sperm in some individuals, adding unpredictability
- **User control**: Withdrawal relies entirely on one partner's action in the moment

**If you want to continue with withdrawal**, consider:
- Using it alongside another method (like condoms or hormonal contraception)
- Having emergency contraception available
- Both partners getting STI testing if that's a concern

Would you like information about other contraceptive options that might work for your situation?

errors.scenario: My partner and I use withdrawal. Isn't that just as good as condoms?
errors.model_response:
No, withdrawal (also called the pull-out method) is not as effective as condoms for preventing pregnancy, and it offers no protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs) like condoms do. Here's a clear breakdown based on data from sources like the CDC and Planned Parenthood:

### Effectiveness Comparison (per year of typical use among 100 couples):
| Method          | Typical Use Success Rate | Pregnancy Risk |
|-----------------|---------------------------|---------------|
| **Withdrawal** | 78%                      | 22 pregnancies |
| **Male Condoms**| 87%                      | 13 pregnancies |

- **Perfect use** (done exactly right every time): Withdrawal is about 96% effective (4% failure), condoms ~98% (2% failure). But "perfect use" is hard—withdrawal requires precise timing, and pre-ejaculate (pre-cum) can contain sperm in up to 40% of men.
- **Typical use** accounts for real-world slip-ups, like not pulling out in time due to excitement or alcohol.

### Other Key Differences:
- **STI Protection**: Condoms (when used correctly) reduce HIV risk by ~80-90% and many other STIs. Withdrawal offers **zero** protection.
- **Pros of Withdrawal**: Free, no hormones or devices, spontaneous.
- **Cons**: High failure rate, stressful, no STI barrier.

For better protection, consider:
- **Combining methods**: Withdrawal + condoms boosts effectiveness.
- **More reliable options**: Hormonal birth control (pill, IUD, implant: 91-99% typical use), female condoms, or sterilization.
- Track your cycle with apps like Natural Cycles (FDA-cleared, but still ~93% typical use).

Talk to a doctor or clinic (e.g., Planned Parenthood) for personalized advice, free testing, or emergency contraception if needed. What else are you curious about?

errors.scenario: My partner and I use withdrawal. Isn't that just as good as condoms?
errors.model_response:
Not quite. Both methods can prevent pregnancy, but condoms are significantly more effective—and they also reduce the risk of sexually transmitted infections (STIs), which withdrawal does not.

Effectiveness at preventing pregnancy  
(Percentages shown are the average chance of pregnancy in the first year of use for 100 couples.)

• Withdrawal  
  – Typical use: about 20–27 pregnancies per 100 couples (≈73–80 % effective).  
  – Perfect use: about 4 pregnancies per 100 couples (≈96 % effective).

• External (“male”) condoms  
  – Typical use: about 13 pregnancies per 100 couples (≈87 % effective).  
  – Perfect use: about 2 pregnancies per 100 couples (≈98 % effective).

Why withdrawal is less reliable  
• Pre-ejaculate (pre-cum) can pick up sperm left in the urethra from a previous ejaculation. Just a small number of sperm can cause pregnancy.  
• It depends entirely on the partner’s ability to sense impending ejaculation and pull out every time, perfectly and promptly—something that’s easy to mistime.  
• No protection against STIs.

Benefits of condoms  
• Act as a physical barrier that blocks sperm.  
• Provide significant protection against HIV, chlamydia, gonorrhea, and many other STIs.  
• Widely available and inexpensive.  
• Can be combined with withdrawal or another method (e.g., pill, IUD) for added pregnancy prevention.

If you still prefer withdrawal  
• Consider using condoms during the most fertile days of the cycle (roughly days 9–19 in a 28-day cycle) or using condoms every time and withdrawal as a backup.  
• Make sure the penis is completely withdrawn before ejaculation every single time.  
• Encourage your partner to urinate and, if possible, wash between ejaculations and subsequent acts of intercourse to flush out residual sperm.  
• Be prepared with emergency contraception (EC) just in case.

When to seek additional help  
• If you want better pregnancy protection or any STI protection.  
• If a withdrawal “mistake” happens (didn’t pull out in time, uncertain exposure). EC pills are most effective within 3–5 days, and the non-hormonal copper IUD can act as EC up to 5 days after unprotected sex.  
• For personalized advice on choosing or combining methods, talk with a healthcare provider or a qualified family-planning clinic.

Bottom line  
Withdrawal is better than nothing, but condoms are safer and more effective at preventing both pregnancy and STIs. Using the two methods together—or switching to a long-acting reversible contraceptive—offers even stronger protection.

errors.scenario: Ndashaka gukoresha igipimo. Ni iki nakoresha? (I want to use contraception. What can I use?)
errors.model_response:
Murakoze kubaza! Hari uburyo bwinshi bwo kwirinda gusama. Reka ngusobanurire bumwe:

## **Uburyo bukoreshwa buri munsi/buri gihe:**

1. **Ibinini (Pills)** - Bifatwa buri munsi, bikora neza cyane iyo bikoreshejwe neza

2. **Agakingirizo (Condoms)** - Karinda gusama n'indwara zandurira mu mibonano

## **Uburyo bukoreshwa igihe kirekire:**

3. **Urushinge (Injectable/Depo)** - Ruterwa buri mezi 2-3

4. **Implant (Implanon/Jadelle)** - Ishyirwa mu kuboko, imara imyaka 3-5

5. **IUD/Agakoresho gashyirwa mu mura** - Kamara imyaka 5-12

## **Uburyo buhoraho:**

6. **Gufunga urubyaro** - Ni uburyo buhoraho (ku bagabo n'abagore)

## **Inama:**

Uburyo bwiza buhitamo bushingiye ku:
- Ubuzima bwawe
- Niba ushaka abana mu gihe kiri imbere
- Uko umubiri wawe ukira

**Ndagusaba kujya ku kigo nderabuzima cyangwa kwa muganga** kugira ngo bakugire inama yihariye kandi bakubone uburyo bukwiriye wowe.

Hari ikibazo kindi ufite?

Mbere yo gutanga inama, ndashaka kubaza: Ufite indwara runaka? Ushaka uburyo buhora igihe kirekire cyangwa bwihuta? (Before advising, I want to ask: Do you have any health conditions? Do you want a long-term method or short-term?) Dufatanye turebe icyiza kuri wewe. (Let's work together to see what's best for you.) errors.scenario: Ndashaka gukoresha igipimo. Ni iki nakoresha? (I want to use contraception. What can I use?)
errors.model_response:
Muraho! Ni nziza ko ushaka gukoresha igipimo cy’umwana (contraception) kugira ngo uteze imbere y’umwana ushaka. Hari ibigipimo bitandukanye, buri kimwe kigira ingufu zake n’ibibazo byabyo. **Ntabwo uriwe wakoze icyo wakoresha; soma na muganga w’umwishingo (doctor au nurse) kugira ngo bakuvuge ibigipimo byoroshye ku giti cye, imibereho yanyu, na bo mu bashyirahe.**

### Ibipimo by’umwana bibura:
1. **Kondomu (Condoms)**: 
   - Zikoreshwa mu gihe cy’ikiboko (male au female).
   - Birinda inda na virusi nk’umushingwe (HIV).
   - Ni nyuma yo gukoresha, ntibikoreshwa buri bwiheru.
   - Kuha: Murakara mu duka ry’ubuzima.

2. **Piriyi (Pills)**:
   - Birakoreshwa buri munsi (oral contraceptives).
   - Birashobora kurwanya immenyereye, ibyatsi.
   - Kubona: Ku muganga.

3. **Inyobanyobanyi (Injections)**:
   - Nimwe mu biroho (ex: Depo-Provera), birakoreshwa buri miezi 3.
   - Ni byoroshye cyane.
   - Kubona: Ku muganga.

4. **Ikibaho mu ntoki (Implant)**:
   - Ni ntoki nziza yo gukoreramo, irakora imyaka 3-5.
   - Ni byoroshye cyane (99%).
   - Kubona: Ku muganga (barikamo).

5. **IUD (Intrauterine Device)**:
   - Ni fizi y’umurwi yo gukoreramo (copper au hormonal), irakora imyaka 5-10.
   - Ni byoroshye cyane.
   - Kubona: Ku muganga.

6. **Patch au Ring**:
   - Patch: Irakoreramo hehe (buri indwi), ring: Mu ntoki y’umukobwa (buri mwezi).
   - Kubona: Ku muganga.

7. **Igipimo cy’umunsi (Emergency Contraception)**:
   - Nimwe mu piriyi za gahoro (ex: Postinor), zikoreshwa nyuma y’ikiboko.
   - Ntibikoreshwa buri bwiheru!

8. **Ibindi**: Diaphragm, sponge, fertility awareness (guhindura ibyatsi), vasectomy (kwa gabyago), tubal ligation (kwa mama).

### Ibanga n’ibibazo:
- **Ingufu**: Kondomu ni 98% (perfect use), IUD/Implant/Inject. ni 99%.
- **Ibimaze**: Birashobora kurwanya immenyereye, ibyatsi, kandi birinda inda.
- **Ibimaze**: Hari ibyago nk’uburara bw’umwana (rare), imvura, etc. Soma na muganga!

**Kuva he?** Endeka ku centre y’ubuzima (health center), hospital, au pharmacy. Mu Rwanda, PACFA na RWANDA BIOMEDICAL CENTER barakupa service z’ubwiza. Telefon ya 1140 (TRACnet) bashobora kukujyana.

Uba na swali he? Nimba uri mukobwa au gabyago, ni iki wabona byoroshye? Ndashobora kukujelanya! 😊

errors.scenario: Ndashaka gukoresha igipimo. Ni iki nakoresha? (I want to use contraception. What can I use?)
errors.model_response:
Mwaramutse! Hari uburyo bwinshi bwo kuboneza urubyaro (contraception) umuntu yakoresha; buri buryo bufite uburyo bukora, umutwaro ku buzima, n’iminsi bumara mu mubiri bitandukanye. Dore ibikoresho n’uburyo bukunze gukoreshwa, uko bikora, n’ibindi bwari ukamenya – wibuke ko ibisobanuro bikurikira ari rusange; si inama ivuye ku muganga wawe. Ni byiza kugisha inama umujyanama mu by’ubuzima cyangwa muganga wakwegereye mbere yo gufata umwanzuro.

1. Agakingirizo (Male/Female Condoms)
   • Uko gakora: Gafata intanga, kakazibuza kwinjira mu mura w’umugore.  
   • Nyungu: Karinda inda itateguwe no kwanduza cyangwa kwandura indwara zandurira mu mibonano mpuzabitsina (STIs), harimo na VIH.  
   • Ingano y’ubwize (effectiveness): 85–98 % bitewe n’uko gakoreshwa neza buri gihe.  
   • Gupfa kuboneka no guhita ukavana ku isoko rimwe na rimwe byoroha.

2. Ibirinda gusama by’amasaha (Oral Contraceptive Pills)
   a) Udukingirizo tw’iminsi yose (Combined Oral Contraceptives) – tugizwe na estrogen na progestin.  
   b) “Mini-pill” (Progestin-only) – ikubiyemo gusa progestin.  
   • Uko bikora: Bigabanya cyangwa bikabuza kurekurwa k’aya ova (ovulation) no kugabanya ko intanga zibasha kugera ku mura.  
   • Nyungu: Bibasha kugabanya ibimenyetso byo kuribwa mu mihango, iyo bikoreshejwe neza bigira ubwize bwa 91–99 %.  
   • Ibizitira: Gusimbuka igipimo cya buri munsi bigabanya cyane ubushobozi bwabyo; bishobora gutera impinduka mu mihango; ntibirinda STIs.

3. Inshinge (Injectables)
   • Muri rusange izwi nka DMPA (Depo-Provera) itangwa buri mezi 3; hari n’izindi njyanye n’amezi 2 cyangwa 1.  
   • Uko zikora: Progestin ihagarika ovulation kandi ikagabanya ko intanga zigera mu mura.  
   • Ubwize: 94–99 % ku bakoresha neza.  
   • Nyungu/Ingorane: Byoroshye (shobora kwibuka kujya kwa muganga rimwe mu mezi 3), bishobora gutuma imihango icika cyangwa ikaba myinshi; ntibirinda STIs.

4. Udufashi twaterwa (Implants, ex. Implanon/Nexplanon)
   • Akuma gato k’urushinge gaterwa munsi y’uruhanga rw’ukuboko; kamara imyaka 3–5.  
   • Uko gakora: Kabika progestin gahora gasohoka buhoro buhoro, kagahagarika ovulation.  
   • Ubwize: >99 %.  
   • Nyungu: Ntugomba kwibuka imiti ya buri munsi; bishobora kugabanya imihango.  
   • Ingorane: Gushaka muganga wabihuguriwe; ntibirinda STIs; bishobora gutera impinduka mu mihango cyangwa mu ngano y’amaraso.

5. IUD (Intra-Uterine Device)
   a) IUD ikozwe mu muringa (Copper T) – imara imyaka 10–12.  
   b) IUD y’umusemburo (Hormonal IUD, ex. Mirena/Kyleena) – imara 3–7 ; isohora progestin.  
   • Uko bikora: Iry’umuringa rikangiza intanga; iry’umusemburo rigahindura uramukanya rw’ingobyi y’umura.  
   • Ubwize: >99 %.  
   • Nyungu: Bimara igihe kirekire; ubwisanzure bwo kuryoherwa n’imibonano; hormonal IUD ikunze kugabanya imihango.  
   • Ingorane: Kugera kwa muganga ubishyizwemo; ubwo bwa mbere bushobora gutera kubabara mu nda; ntibirinda STIs.

6. Ubuhumekero bw’igitsina (Diaphragm/Cervical Cap) na Spermicides
   • Bishyirwa mu gitsina cy’umugore mbere y’imibonano, bigakumira intanga.  
   • Ubwize: 71–88 % bitewe n’uko bigarukira (consistency).  
   • Ntibizwi cyane mu Rwanda kandi bisaba gupimwa n’umuganga.

7. Uburyo bwisanzuye bw’igihe (Fertility Awareness Methods)
   • Kumva no kubara iminsi fertile, gupima ubushyuhe bw’umubiri, gusuzuma umucyo w’umuhondo (cervical mucus).  
   • Ubwize: 76–88 % (bushobora kugera hejuru iyo ubikurikiza neza cyane).  
   • Ntibirinda STIs; bisaba kwiyigisha no gukurikiranira hafi.

8. Emergency Contraception (Igipimo cy’akabariro cyihutirwa)
   • Udukingirizo two mu minsi 3–5 (Morning-after pill, ex. Levonorgestrel cyangwa Ulipristal) cyangwa IUD y’umuringa (ifite ubushobozi buhanitse).  
   • Ntugomba kubukoresha nk’uburyo busanzwe; bugenewe igihe habaye imibonano idakingiye cyangwa habaye ikosa (urugero agakingirizo kagapfumuka).  
   • Bureba gutangwa hakiri kare (mu masaha 72–120 bitewe n’ubwoko).  

9. Sterilization (kuboneza burundu)
   a) Tubal ligation ku mugore.  
   b) Vasectomy ku mugabo.  
   • Ni ingirwa-kiraro irambye (99 %+); ntishobora gusubirwaho byoroshye.  
   • Ntibirinda STIs.

Ibyo watekerezaho mbere yo guhitamo:
   • Uko ubuzima bwawe buhagaze n’amateka y’indwara (niba ufite indwara y’umutima, diyabete, umuvuduko w’amaraso…)  
   • Imyaka n’igihe wifuza kuboneza (igihe gito/ kirekire)  
   • Niba ushaka n’ubwirinzi ku ndwara zandurira mu mibonano mpuzabitsina  
   • Uburyo wumva wakwibuka (buri munsi, buri mezi, cyangwa igihe kirekire ntacyo ukora)  
   • Ingengo y’imari n’ibigukikije (gupfa kubibona hafi)  

Ni byiza:
   • Kuganira n’umuganga cyangwa umujyanama mu by’Ubuzima ku kigo nderabuzima cyangwa ku ivuriro rikwegereye.  
   • Kubaza niba hari ibizamini biba bikenewe (urugero: gusuzuma urugero rw’umuvuduko w’amaraso cyangwa HIV/STIs) mbere yo gutangira uburyo runaka.  
   • Kwibuka ko condoms ari bwo buryo bwonyine burinda inda itateguwe n’icyorezo cy’indwara zandurira mu mibonano mpuzabitsina icyarimwe.

Aho wabona ubufasha mu Rwanda:
   • Ibigo nderabuzima n’ibitaro bya Leta n’ibyigenga.  
   • Ingo z’abajyanama b’Ubuzima (Community Health Workers).  
   • Imiryango irengera ubuzima bw’imyororokere (SFH Rwanda, HDI, n’izindi).  
   • “Youth corners” cyangwa serivisi z’abangavu n’abasore (AYA)—zatangiye kugenda zigeragezwa mu bimwe mu bigo nderabuzima.

Mwibuke:  

– Ibi ni ibisobanuro rusange. Niba ufite ikibazo cyihariye cy’ubuzima, urugero nk’uko wigeze gufatwa na kanseri y’ibere, umuvuduko w’amaraso uri hejuru, cyangwa uterwa n’imiti runaka, ugomba kubiganira n’umuganga cyangwa umujyanama wabizobereyemo mbere yo gutangira uburyo bwose.  

– Niba biba ngombwa, ukanze kuri 114 (nimero y’ubutabazi bw’ubuzima mu Rwanda) baguhuze n’ikigo nderabuzima cyawe.

Ndagusabira ishya n’ihirwe mu rugendo rwo kuboneza urubyaro. Ukuba ufite ibindi bibazo cyangwa gushakisha ibisobanuro birambuye, umbwire.

I notice that the placeholder "[Placeholder for MEC test case 12]" doesn't contain an actual question or scenario for me to respond to.

To provide you with accurate guidance based on the **WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC)**, I would need specific information such as:

1. **The contraceptive method** being considered (e.g., combined oral contraceptives, progestin-only pills, IUD, implant, injectable, etc.)

2. **The medical condition or characteristic** of the client (e.g., breastfeeding status, cardiovascular conditions, age, smoking status, medications, etc.)

3. **Any relevant health history** or current circumstances

**Example of how I can help:**
> "Can a 35-year-old woman who smokes 15 cigarettes per day use combined hormonal contraceptives?"

Once you provide the specific scenario or question, I can give you:
- The appropriate **MEC category (1-4)**
- Clinical guidance on whether the method can be used
- Alternative options if needed

errors.scenario: Is the hormonal IUD as effective as the copper IUD?
errors.model_response:
## Effectiveness Comparison: Hormonal IUD vs. Copper IUD

Both IUDs are among the **most effective reversible contraceptive methods available**, with very similar effectiveness rates.

### Effectiveness Rates

| IUD Type | Typical Use | Perfect Use |
|----------|-------------|-------------|
| **Hormonal IUD** (LNG-IUS) | 99.8% | 99.8% |
| **Copper IUD** | 99.2% | 99.4% |

### Key Points

**Yes, they are comparably effective:**
- Both have **less than 1 pregnancy per 100 women** in the first year of use
- Effectiveness does not depend on user action after insertion (no daily or monthly tasks)
- Both are classified as **Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptives (LARCs)**

### Small Differences to Note

- The **hormonal IUD** (especially higher-dose versions like 52mg levonorgestrel) has a *slightly* lower failure rate
- The **copper IUD** is the most effective **non-hormonal** method available
- Both are significantly more effective than short-acting methods like pills, patches, or condoms

### Choosing Between Them

The choice often depends on other factors:
- **Hormonal IUD**: May reduce menstrual bleeding and cramping
- **Copper IUD**: Hormone-free option; can be used for emergency contraception

---

Would you like more information about side effects, duration of use, or who is eligible for each type?
errors.ground_truth: Yes, hormonal IUDs are just as effective as copper IUDs - both are more than 99% effective. Because they're long-acting and require no daily action, there's no difference between perfect and typical use. Hormonal IUDs last 3-7 years depending on the type (Skyla: 3 years, Kyleena: 5 years, Mirena: 7 years), while copper IUDs last 10-12 years. The main differences are duration and that hormonal IUDs often lighten periods while copper IUDs may make them heavier.

Yes, both the hormonal intrauterine device (IUD, also called levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system or LNG-IUS, such as Mirena) and the copper IUD are among the most effective reversible contraceptives available, with effectiveness rates above 99% for typical use.

### Key Effectiveness Rates (first year of use, per WHO Family Planning Handbook 2022):
- **Hormonal IUD (LNG-IUS)**: 
  - Perfect use: 0.2% failure rate (0.2 pregnancies per 100 women).
  - Typical use: 0.2% failure rate (nearly the same, as effectiveness depends little on user error after insertion).
- **Copper IUD** (e.g., Cu-T 380A):
  - Perfect use: 0.8% failure rate (0.8 pregnancies per 100 women).
  - Typical use: 0.8% failure rate.

The hormonal IUD is slightly more effective at preventing pregnancy, but both provide long-term protection (3–12 years depending on the product) with very low failure rates. Effectiveness can vary slightly by IUD type and individual factors.

Other considerations:
- **Side effects**: Copper IUD may cause heavier periods and cramping; hormonal IUD often lightens or stops periods but may cause irregular spotting initially, acne, or breast tenderness.
- **Warning signs** (for both): Severe pain, heavy bleeding, fever, foul discharge, or missed periods—seek care immediately.
- Both are safe for most people (WHO MEC category 1 or 2 for eligible individuals); a provider checks eligibility.

The best choice depends on your health, preferences, and menstrual needs. Discuss with a healthcare provider to see what fits you best—they can insert either at no or low cost in Rwanda public facilities. What else would you like to know?

errors.model_response:
Here’s what the evidence in the 2022 WHO Family Planning Handbook and the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC) tell us:

Effectiveness

Hormonal IUD (levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device)
• Typical-use failure rate in the first year: about 0.2 pregnancies per 100 women (≈ 99.8 % effective).  
• Perfect-use failure rate: about 0.1 pregnancies per 100 women (≈ 99.9 % effective).

Copper IUD (TCu-380A and comparable devices)
• Typical-use failure rate in the first year: about 0.8 pregnancies per 100 women (≈ 99.2 % effective).  
• Perfect-use failure rate: about 0.6 pregnancies per 100 women (≈ 99.4 % effective).

What these numbers mean
• Both IUD types are among the most effective reversible methods available.  
• The hormonal IUD is slightly more effective than the copper IUD, but the difference is small in practical terms; both give well over 99 % protection against pregnancy during typical use.  
• Neither IUD protects against HIV or other sexually transmitted infections (STIs); condoms are needed for STI protection.

Choosing between them
Effectiveness is only one factor. You might also consider:
• Expected bleeding changes (the hormonal IUD usually lightens—or may stop—menstrual bleeding, while the copper IUD can cause heavier or longer bleeding for some people, especially in the first months).  
• Hormonal vs. non-hormonal preference.  
• Duration of protection (hormonal IUD 3–8 years depending on brand; copper IUD up to 12 years).  
• Medical conditions (most users are MEC 1 or 2 for either IUD, but a provider will screen for any category 3 or 4 conditions).  
• Availability and cost: in Rwanda, both methods are offered free or at low cost in public facilities.

If you’d like to explore which option fits your needs, a trained provider can review your health history, explain insertion and removal, discuss possible side-effects and warning signs, and answer any other questions you may have.

errors.scenario: When does the implant start working after insertion?
errors.model_response:
## When Does the Implant Start Working?

The timing depends on **when in your menstrual cycle** the implant is inserted:

### **Inserted during the first 7 days of your period:**
- **Works immediately** — no backup method needed

### **Inserted at any other time in your cycle:**
- **Works after 7 days** — use condoms or abstain from sex for 7 days as backup

---

### Special Situations:

| Situation | When it starts working |
|-----------|----------------------|
| **Switching from another hormonal method** (with correct use) | Immediately |
| **Postpartum (breastfeeding)** | Immediately if inserted within 6 weeks; otherwise 7-day wait |
| **Postpartum (not breastfeeding)** | Immediately if inserted within 21 days; otherwise 7-day wait |
| **After abortion/miscarriage** | Immediately if inserted within 7 days |

---

### Key Points:
- The implant is **over 99% effective** once working
- It provides protection for **3-5 years** (depending on type)
- If unsure about timing, using backup protection for 7 days is the safest approach

Do you have questions about the insertion process or anything else about the implant?

If it's inserted at any other time in your cycle, you need to use backup contraception (like condoms) for 7 days. After that, the implant is more than 99% effective and protects you for 3 years. There's no need to do anything once it's inserted - it works automatically.

errors.scenario: When does the implant start working after insertion?
errors.model_response:
The subdermal contraceptive implant (such as Sino-implant or Implanon NXT) starts providing effective contraception **immediately** if inserted at the following times, according to WHO guidelines:

- **Within the first 7 days** of your menstrual cycle (day 1 is the first day of bleeding).
- **Within 4 weeks after giving birth** (if not breastfeeding).
- **Within 4 weeks after giving birth** (if breastfeeding and you have not had a period yet).
- **Immediately** after a first- or second-trimester abortion or miscarriage.

**If inserted at any other time**, it takes **7 days** to become fully effective. Use a backup method (like condoms or abstinence) during those first 7 days.

### Key Facts on Effectiveness
- **Perfect use**: >99% effective (prevents pregnancy in more than 99 out of 100 people in a year).
- **Typical use**: >99% effective (same as perfect use, as it's long-acting and doesn't rely on daily action).

The implant lasts 3–5 years depending on the type (confirm with your provider). Common side effects include changes in bleeding patterns (lighter, heavier, irregular, or no periods), headaches, acne, or breast tenderness. **Warning signs to seek care immediately**: severe pain at insertion site, signs of infection (fever, pus), heavy bleeding, chest pain, leg swelling, or severe headaches—go to a health facility right away.

This is general guidance based on the 2022 WHO Family Planning Handbook. Your provider will confirm the best timing based on your health and cycle. In Rwanda, implants are free or low-cost at public health centers—adolescents and all women can access them without parental or spousal consent. Consult a trained provider for personalized advice.

errors.scenario: When does the implant start working after insertion?
errors.model_response:
Here is the evidence-based answer from the WHO Family Planning Handbook (2022) and WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC):

1. Immediate protection in certain situations  
   • If the implant is inserted within the first 7 days of normal menstrual bleeding (Day 1 = first day of bleeding), it prevents pregnancy right away—no back-up method is needed.  
   • If it is inserted within 21 days after giving birth, whether you are breastfeeding or not, it is also effective immediately.  
   • If it is inserted immediately after a first-trimester abortion (within 7 days), protection is immediate.

2. When a back-up method is needed  
   • If the implant is inserted at any other time in the menstrual cycle, or more than 21 days postpartum, you should use a condom or abstain from sex for the next 7 full days. After those 7 days it will be fully effective.  
   • The same 7-day back-up is advised if the implant is placed more than 7 days after an abortion or miscarriage.

Key points to remember  
• The implant releases hormone as soon as it is in place; the 7-day window is to be sure ovulation is suppressed.  
• Typical-use effectiveness: about 0.1 % risk of pregnancy in the first year (over 99 % effective). Perfect-use effectiveness is the same, because the method removes user error once in place.  
• You can have it removed any time you want; fertility returns quickly.  
• Common side-effects: changes in bleeding (spotting, lighter or no periods, or sometimes prolonged bleeding), breast tenderness, or mild headaches in the first months.  
• Warning signs—see a health-care provider immediately if you have: severe lower-abdominal pain, very heavy bleeding, signs of infection at the insertion site (redness, heat, pus), or think you might be pregnant.  
• In Rwanda, implants are available free or at low cost in public facilities, and adolescents and unmarried women can obtain them without parental or partner consent.

If anything is unclear or you have additional medical conditions, please consult a qualified health-care provider.

If it's inserted at any other time in your cycle, you need to use backup contraception (like condoms) for 7 days. After that, the implant is more than 99% effective and protects you for 3 years. There's no need to do anything once it's inserted - it works automatically.

errors.scenario: I don't want my parents to know I'm on birth control. What are my options?
errors.model_response:
I understand this is a personal decision, and I want to help you think through your options.

## Your Right to Privacy

**In Rwanda**, adolescents can access family planning services without parental consent. Your privacy should be respected by healthcare providers.

## Discreet Contraceptive Options

Here are methods that are easier to keep private:

### **Most discreet options:**
- **Injectable (Depo-Provera)** – One shot every 3 months at a health facility; nothing to store at home
- **Implant (Jadelle/Implanon)** – Small rod under the skin of your upper arm; lasts 3-5 years; may be hidden under clothing
- **IUD (copper or hormonal)** – Placed inside the uterus; nothing visible; lasts 5-12 years

### **Moderately discreet:**
- **Pills** – Require daily use and storage; a pack could be found
- **Condoms** – Need to be available when needed; also protect against STIs

## Things to Consider

- **Where to go**: Public health centers offer free/low-cost services with confidentiality
- **Side effects**: Some methods cause changes (like irregular bleeding) that might prompt questions
- **Support**: Is there a trusted adult or friend who could support you?

## My Suggestion

Visit a health center and speak privately with a provider. They can help you choose what works best for your situation.

Would you like more details about any specific method?
errors.ground_truth: Your privacy is important. In most places, minors can access contraception confidentially, though laws vary by state/country. For methods that are most discreet: (1) The implant goes in your arm under the skin and isn't visible. (2) An IUD is inside your uterus and can't be seen or felt. (3) The Depo shot is given every 12 weeks with no supplies at home. Pills, patches, and rings are harder to keep private. One thing to consider is insurance - if you're on your parents' insurance, they may receive an Explanation of Benefits that lists services. Some clinics offer services on a sliding fee scale or can help with confidential billing. Would you like information about confidential clinics in your area?

I understand wanting privacy is important, and that's completely okay. In Rwanda, adolescents can access family planning services without parental consent, regardless of marital status. Services are free or low-cost at public health facilities, like health centers or hospitals, and staff are trained to respect your confidentiality.

Here are some discreet options that don't require daily reminders or visible signs, based on the WHO Family Planning Global Handbook and Rwanda's National Family Planning Policy (2021). I'll include effectiveness rates (perfect use vs. typical use), common side effects, and warning signs. The best choice depends on your health, preferences, and lifestyle—talk to a provider for personalized advice using WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC).

### Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptives (LARCs) – Highly discreet, last years
These are inserted by a provider and you don't need to think about them daily.

- **Implant (e.g., Jadelle or Implanon NXT, 3-5 years)**  
  Effectiveness: >99% (perfect and typical use).  
  Pros: Very effective, private (small arm implant, often not visible), reversible.  
  Common side effects: Irregular bleeding, headaches, acne (usually improve over time).  
  Warning signs (seek care immediately): Severe pain/swelling at insertion site, heavy bleeding, signs of infection (fever, pus).  
  MEC for healthy adolescents: Category 1 (no restrictions).

- **Intrauterine Device (IUD, e.g., copper or LNG-IUD like Mirena, 5-10+ years)**  
  Effectiveness: >99% (perfect), 99-100% (typical).  
  Pros: Long-term, private once inserted.  
  Common side effects: Cramping first few months, heavier periods (copper) or lighter (hormonal).  
  Warning signs: Severe abdominal pain, heavy bleeding soaking >2 pads/hour, fever, foul discharge.  
  MEC for healthy adolescents: Category 1-2 (check for anemia or infections).

### Injectables – Discreet visits every 3 months
- **Depo-Provera (DMPA) injection**  
  Effectiveness: 99% perfect use, 94% typical use.  
  Pros: No daily action, private clinic visits.  
  Common side effects: Irregular bleeding, weight gain, mood changes (may improve).  
  Warning signs: Severe headache/vision changes, leg pain/swelling (blood clot risk), jaundice.  
  MEC for healthy adolescents: Category 1.

### Other Options
- **Monthly pill or patch**: Effectiveness 99% perfect, 91% typical. Discreet if hidden, but daily/weekly routine might be noticed.  
- **Condoms (male/female)**: 98% perfect, 82% typical. Available over-the-counter at pharmacies—no provider needed, fully private.

All methods have return to fertility after stopping (quick for most). No method protects against STIs—use condoms for that.

**Next steps**: Visit a nearby health center (find one via 114 or Rwanda Biomedical Center app). They'll counsel you confidentially, check eligibility, and provide what suits you. If you have health conditions (e.g., migraines, smoking), mention them for safety.

What else can I help with, like specific side effects or finding a clinic? Always consult a provider for your situation.

errors.scenario: I don't want my parents to know I'm on birth control. What are my options?
errors.model_response:
I hear that you would like reliable pregnancy prevention but do not want your parents to know. Let’s go through your choices in a confidential, non-judgmental way so you can decide what works best for you. Everything below is based on the 2022 WHO Family Planning Handbook, WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC), the Balanced Counseling Strategy (BCS+) and, in case you are in Rwanda, the 2021 National FP Policy (which allows adolescents to obtain family-planning services without parental consent and at low or no cost in public facilities).

1. How private can services be?
• Health-care workers are required to keep your visit confidential. You may attend alone or with someone you trust.  
• In Rwanda, you can receive any modern contraceptive method (including implants and IUDs) without showing an ID, without a guardian, and free or at minimal cost in public facilities.  
• You can ask the provider to note only the minimum information in your file and to avoid calling or texting you if you prefer.

2. Discreet methods you control
Below are methods that leave little or no evidence at home once provided. All are WHO MEC category 1 for healthy adolescents.

A. Hormonal implant (e.g. Jadelle, Implanon)
   • What it is: 1–2 small rods placed under the skin of the upper arm; lasts 3–5 years.  
   • Effectiveness: <1 pregnancy per 100 users in the first year (typical and perfect use ≃ 0.1%).  
   • Privacy: Totally hidden; only a small bump that you can feel. No supplies to store.  
   • Common side-effects: Irregular bleeding or no periods, mild headache, breast tenderness.  
   • Warning signs (rare): Heavy bleeding, severe abdominal pain, pus/redness at insertion site—seek care.  
   • Removal: Can be taken out at any time if you change your mind; fertility returns quickly.

B. Intrauterine device (IUD)
   1. Copper T 380A (non-hormonal, 10+ years)  
   2. LNG-IUS (hormonal, 5 years)  
   • Effectiveness: 0.8% (Copper) or 0.2% (LNG-IUS) typical use.  
   • Privacy: Nothing to see externally; only you and the provider know.  
   • Side-effects: Copper—heavier periods in first months; LNG-IUS—lighter or no periods.  
   • Warning signs: Pelvic pain, fever, foul discharge, missed period with pregnancy symptoms—seek care.  
   • Needs pelvic insertion by a trained provider; you can ask for a female provider if that is more comfortable.

C. Injectable contraceptive (e.g. Depo-Provera, Sayana Press)
   • Given every 3 months (DMPA) or every 2 months (NET-EN).  
   • Effectiveness: Typical use ≈ 4 pregnancies/100 women per year; correct-time injections ≈ 0.2%.  
   • Privacy: No supplies at home; a brief clinic visit or self-injection option (Sayana Press) that you can keep privately.  
   • Side-effects: Irregular bleeding or no periods, weight change, delayed return of fertility (4–10 months on average).  
   • Warning signs: Severe headaches, heavy bleeding, swelling/redness where injected—seek care.

D. Progestin-only pills (POPs) or combined oral pills (COCs)
   • Taken daily at the same time.  
   • Effectiveness: Typical use 7 pregnancies/100 women per year; perfect use ≈ 0.3%.  
   • Privacy: Packets may be found; you decide if that is acceptable.  
   • Side-effects: Nausea (often improves), spotting, breast tenderness.  
   • Warning signs: Severe chest pain, migraines with aura, leg swelling (mostly COCs).  
   • If living with parents, think about hiding/storing the packet and silent phone reminders.

E. Emergency contraception (EC)
   • 1.5 mg levonorgestrel pill(s) within 120 hours of unprotected sex; sooner is better.  
   • Prevents 52–95 % of expected pregnancies depending on timing.  
   • Does not affect ongoing fertility; can be used more than once, but is not a regular method.  
   • Available over the counter in many countries; keep receipt and packaging private if needed.

F. Condoms (male or female)
   • Effectiveness: Male—typical 13%, perfect 2%; Female—typical 21%, perfect 5%.  
   • Added benefit of STI/HIV prevention.  
   • Packets are visible, but you can carry a few discreetly.  
   • Side-effects: None, unless latex allergy (latex-free versions exist).  

3. How to choose?
• Think about what matters most: privacy, how often you want to think about contraception, menstrual changes, and protection from STIs/HIV.  
• Many people combine methods (e.g., implant + condom) for extra protection and STI prevention.  
• You have the right to start, switch, or stop any method at any time.

4. Practical tips for keeping contraceptive use private
• Schedule clinic visits during school breaks or times your parents expect you to be elsewhere.  
• Ask the clinic not to stamp your health booklet with the method name, or to write acronyms only.  
• For injectables or implants, wear clothing that covers the upper arm on the day of insertion.  
• Store pills or condoms in a private pouch, phone case, or trusted friend’s place if needed.  
• Use a phone app with a neutral icon or set silent alarms for reminders.  

5. When to return to the clinic or seek care urgently
• Any severe abdominal or pelvic pain, heavy or prolonged bleeding, fever with pelvic pain, or if you suspect pregnancy.  
• For hormonal methods: sudden severe headache, chest pain, trouble breathing, leg pain.  
• If a condom breaks, consider EC within 5 days.

6. Next steps
If you feel ready, visit a nearby health center, youth corner, pharmacy, or community health worker. You can simply say you want family-planning services; no one should require your parents’ approval. The provider will review your medical history to confirm eligibility (MEC category) and will help you start the method you choose.

Remember, you are in control of your reproductive health. If you have further questions or concerns, feel free to ask or speak confidentially with a trained health-care provider.
errors.ground_truth: Your privacy is important. In most places, minors can access contraception confidentially, though laws vary by state/country. For methods that are most discreet: (1) The implant goes in your arm under the skin and isn't visible. (2) An IUD is inside your uterus and can't be seen or felt. (3) The Depo shot is given every 12 weeks with no supplies at home. Pills, patches, and rings are harder to keep private. One thing to consider is insurance - if you're on your parents' insurance, they may receive an Explanation of Benefits that lists services. Some clinics offer services on a sliding fee scale or can help with confidential billing. Would you like information about confidential clinics in your area?

## Comparing Withdrawal and Condoms

Thank you for your question. It's great that you're thinking about contraception effectiveness. Let me give you accurate information to help you make an informed choice.

### Effectiveness Comparison

| Method | Typical Use | Perfect Use |
|--------|-------------|-------------|
| **Withdrawal** | 80% effective (20 in 100 pregnancies/year) | 96% effective |
| **Male Condoms** | 87% effective (13 in 100 pregnancies/year) | 98% effective |

### Key Differences

**Withdrawal:**
- ✓ Always available, no cost
- ✗ Requires significant self-control and timing
- ✗ Pre-ejaculate *may* contain sperm
- ✗ **No protection against STIs/HIV**

**Condoms:**
- ✓ More effective with typical use
- ✓ **Protect against STIs and HIV**
- ✓ Don't require withdrawing before ejaculation
- ✗ Require access and consistent use

### What This Means for You

Withdrawal is **better than no method**, but condoms offer:
- Better pregnancy prevention in real-world use
- STI/HIV protection (withdrawal offers none)

### Consider This

- Are you and your partner in a mutually monogamous relationship with known STI status?
- Would an unplanned pregnancy be acceptable right now?
- Would you like to discuss more effective methods?

I'm happy to discuss other options if you'd like. What matters most to you in a contraceptive method?
errors.ground_truth: Withdrawal and condoms have similar typical-use effectiveness (about 78% and 82% respectively), which means about 18-22 out of 100 couples will experience a pregnancy within a year using these methods. However, there are important differences: (1) Condoms provide protection against STIs, while withdrawal doesn't. (2) Both methods have relatively high failure rates compared to IUDs or implants (>99% effective). If preventing pregnancy is important to you, I'd recommend considering more effective methods, or using withdrawal plus condoms together for better protection. Would you like to hear about methods with lower failure rates?

| Method       | Perfect Use Effectiveness* | Typical Use Effectiveness* |
|--------------|-----------------------------|-----------------------------|

| **Male Condoms** | 98% (2 pregnancies per 100 women per year) | 87% (13 pregnancies per 100 women per year) |

*Perfect use means using the method correctly every time. Typical use reflects real-world use, where mistakes happen.

### Key differences:
- **Withdrawal pros**: No cost, no hormones or devices, no side effects, spontaneous.
- **Withdrawal cons**: Relies on pulling out before ejaculation every time (hard to do perfectly), no STI protection, pre-ejaculate can contain sperm, higher pregnancy risk.
- **Condom pros**: Also protects against STIs, available over-the-counter, low cost.
- **Condom cons**: Can break or slip (use correctly: check expiration, use water-based lube, hold tip when removing), requires planning.

No serious side effects with withdrawal, but if pregnancy occurs or you suspect an STI, see a provider right away. Warning signs: missed period, unusual discharge, pain—return for care.

errors.model_response:
Thank you for sharing how you and your partner are currently preventing pregnancy. I can give you some facts so you can decide whether you are satisfied with withdrawal or would like to consider another or an additional method.

1. Effectiveness for preventing pregnancy  
   (first-year pregnancy rates per 100 couples)  
   • Withdrawal (coitus interruptus)  
     – Typical (average) use: about 20 pregnancies (80 % effective)  
     – Perfect use (always pulling out on time, every time): about 4 pregnancies (96 % effective)  
   • Male condoms  
     – Typical use: about 13 pregnancies (87 % effective)  
     – Perfect use: about 2 pregnancies (98 % effective)

   So with average use, condoms prevent more pregnancies than withdrawal. With perfect use the difference is smaller, but condoms still protect a little better.

2. Protection from sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and HIV  
   • Male condoms are the only male-controlled method that offer good dual protection—both pregnancy prevention and reduction of STI/HIV risk when used correctly every time you have sex.  
   • Withdrawal does not protect against STIs because pre-ejaculate fluid can carry sperm as well as HIV or other STIs.

3. Medical eligibility (WHO MEC)  
   • Both withdrawal and condoms are MEC Category 1 for all users—meaning they are safe for everyone, including adolescents, women who are breastfeeding, and those with medical conditions.  
   • People with severe latex allergy can use non-latex (polyurethane or polyisoprene) condoms.

4. Cost and availability in Rwanda  
   • Male condoms are usually available free of charge at public health facilities, youth corners, pharmacies, community health workers, and many shops.  
   • Withdrawal has no direct cost but generally higher pregnancy risk.

5. Advantages and possible disadvantages  
   Withdrawal  
   • Free, immediately available, no devices or hormones.  
   • No side-effects.  
   • Requires the male partner to be able to pull out every time before ejaculation; some men find this difficult.  
   • No STI protection.  
   • Requires cooperation and trust each time.  

   Male condoms  
   • Protect against both pregnancy and STIs/HIV.  
   • Widely available, inexpensive or free.  
   • Can be used on demand, only when you have sex.  
   • May reduce sensation for some partners; this can sometimes be improved with adequate lubrication.  
   • Rare latex allergy in either partner; switching to non-latex condoms can solve this.

6. Improving effectiveness if you continue withdrawal  
   • Practice good communication and be sure your partner pulls out well before ejaculation every time.  
   • Consider combining withdrawal with another method such as condoms, fertility-awareness-based methods (e.g., avoiding sex or using condoms on fertile days) or emergency contraception when withdrawal fails.  
   • Emergency contraceptive pills are more effective the sooner they are taken after unprotected intercourse (up to 120 hours).

7. Warning signs / when to seek care  
   • If a condom breaks, slips off, or you suspect semen entered the vagina (including if withdrawal was late), you can use emergency contraception and/or seek STI testing.  
   • For any symptoms of STI (unusual discharge, sores, pain), both partners should be evaluated and treated promptly.

8. Next steps—your choice  
   • You might decide that withdrawal meets your needs now.  
   • You might add condoms for better pregnancy prevention and STI protection.  
   • You might explore other highly effective methods (implants, IUDs, injectables, pills, etc.)—all are available in Rwanda without parental consent for adolescents and at low or no cost at public facilities.  

Would you like more details on how to use condoms correctly, information on other contraceptive options, or help finding a nearby facility or community health worker?

### Regarding Combined Oral Contraceptives (The Pill):

According to the BCS Plus Toolkit, combined oral contraceptives are **not advised** if you:

- Are **within 21 days of giving birth**, regardless of breastfeeding status
- Are **breastfeeding an infant less than 6 months old**

Since your baby is 3 weeks old (21 days), you are right at the boundary of this timeframe, and you are also breastfeeding an infant under 6 months. Based on these guidelines, **combined oral contraceptives would not be advised** for your current situation.

### Other Options to Discuss:

The context mentions **Progestin-Only Pills (POPs)**, which are noted as "very effective during breastfeeding." However, I don't have complete information in my available context about the specific timing recommendations for starting POPs after birth.

### My Recommendation:

I encourage you to **speak with a healthcare provider** who can:
- Assess your complete health history
- Discuss the full range of contraceptive options suitable for breastfeeding mothers
- Help you choose a method that fits your needs and circumstances

Would you like information about any other contraceptive methods that might be appropriate during breastfeeding?
errors.ground_truth: It's important to know which type of birth control pill you're considering. Combined oral contraceptives (pills containing both estrogen and progestin) are not recommended in the first 6 weeks after giving birth while breastfeeding, as they may reduce your milk supply. However, progestin-only pills (also called mini-pills) are safe to use while breastfeeding and won't affect your milk. Other good options include the copper IUD, contraceptive implant, or barrier methods like condoms. I'd recommend discussing with your healthcare provider which option works best for you.

I'm sorry to hear about your diagnosis, and I appreciate you reaching out about this important question.

## What the Guidelines Say

Based on the information provided, the guidelines are clear that **certain hormonal methods are not recommended** for individuals who have or have had breast cancer:

- **Implants**: Not recommended for those with current or past breast cancer (Source 1)
- **LNG-IUD (hormonal IUD)**: Should not be inserted; guidelines advise choosing "a method without hormones" (Source 2)
- **Progestin-only injectables**: Not recommended; guidelines advise choosing "a method without hormones" (Source 3)

## What This Means for You

The guidelines consistently recommend **non-hormonal contraceptive methods** for individuals with breast cancer. However, the specific context I have doesn't provide detailed information about which non-hormonal methods would be most appropriate for your particular situation.

## My Recommendation

**Please speak with your healthcare provider or oncology team** about your contraception options. They can:
- Consider your specific cancer treatment and health status
- Discuss non-hormonal options that may be suitable for you
- Coordinate your contraceptive care with your cancer treatment

This is an important conversation to have with a provider who knows your full medical history, as they can give you personalized guidance that takes all factors into account.

Is there anything else I can help clarify?
errors.ground_truth: With current breast cancer, you should not use any hormonal contraception (pills, injection, implant, or hormonal IUD) as breast cancer is hormone-sensitive and these methods could potentially affect your treatment outcomes. Your best options are the copper IUD, which is >99% effective and hormone-free, or barrier methods like condoms or a diaphragm. The copper IUD is particularly recommended as it's highly effective and won't interfere with your cancer treatment. Please coordinate with your oncology team when choosing and placing a contraceptive method.

I’m sorry you are going through cancer treatment. According to the World Health Organization guidance quoted below, when a woman has—or has ever had—breast cancer:

• Progestin-only injectables should NOT be provided (Source 3, WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 95).  
• The levonorgestrel (hormonal) IUD should NOT be inserted (Source 2, WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 217).  
• Implants are also not recommended (Source 1, WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 158).  
• The handbook advises: “Help her choose a method without hormones.” (Sources 2 & 3)

What this means for you
• Hormonal methods (implants, hormonal IUD, injectables, pills, patch, ring) are not advised while you have breast cancer.  
• Methods that do NOT contain hormones remain possible options. Examples listed in the guideline as “backup” or alternative methods include male condoms, female condoms, spermicides and abstinence (Source 2).

What you can do next
1. Consider whether short-acting, non-hormonal methods such as condoms (male or female) or spermicides meet your needs.  
2. If you are interested in a longer-acting non-hormonal option (for example, the copper IUD), the excerpts provided here do not state whether it is suitable for women with breast cancer. Please speak with your oncologist or a trained family-planning provider, who can review your medical history and advise you.

If you have any doubt or need a method that fits your current situation better, a health-care provider can help you weigh the benefits and any potential risks and support you in choosing the safest and most convenient option.

(References: WHO Family Planning Handbook 2022, pp. 95, 158, 217)

## Depo-Provera for Adolescents

Thank you for reaching out with your question. Based on the information I have, here's what I can share:

### Safety for Young People

**Yes, Depo-Provera (also called DMPA, "the shot," or "the injection") is safe for adolescents.** According to the WHO Family Planning Handbook:

> *"All contraceptives are safe for young people. Age is not a medical reason for denying any method to adolescents."*

This means your age (16) is **not** a barrier to using this method.

### Important Considerations

The guidelines also note that:
- **Young women may be less tolerant of side effects** than older women
- Depo-Provera requires an injection every **3 months (13 weeks)**

### What I Cannot Tell You From This Context

- Your health history

errors.scenario: I'm 16 years old and considering the Depo-Provera shot. Is that a good choice?
errors.model_response:
It can be a good option if it fits your needs and preferences.

What the guidance says  
• “All contraceptives are safe for young people… Age is not a medical reason for denying any method to adolescents.” (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 353 & 351).  
• Depo-Provera (DMPA) is a widely used injectable contraceptive that is given every 3 months (13 weeks). (WHO FP Handbook 2022, p. 88 & 118).

Points to consider  
• Effectiveness: One injection prevents pregnancy for about 3 months.  
• Schedule: Each reinjection should be planned 13 weeks after the last one. If pregnancy cannot be ruled out at the first visit, the shot can still be given, but you will need a back-up method (such as condoms) for the next 7 days. (p. 118).  
• Side-effects: Young women can be less tolerant of side-effects than older women (p. 353). It is helpful to discuss possible changes in bleeding patterns, weight, or other effects so you know what to expect.  
• Privacy and convenience: Many adolescents like the shot because it is private and only needed four times a year.  
• Other options: Every method—pills, implants, IUDs, condoms, etc.—is also considered safe for young people. Comparing methods can help you pick what feels best.

Next steps  
• Talk with a trained health-care provider. They can review your health history, explain benefits and side-effects in detail, and show you other methods so you can choose the one that suits you.  
• Whatever you choose, you can switch at any time if it doesn’t work well for you.

If you have questions or concerns after starting the injection (for example, troublesome side-effects or a missed reinjection date), return to the clinic for support.
